Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Understanding and controlling photoinduced self-exchange reactions across sensitized mesoporous thin films to drive multiple-electron-transfer catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Shane Ardo of the University of California-Irvine is supported by the Chemical Catalysis program in the Division of Chemistry to investigate dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). DSSCs are an inexpensive alternative to commercial solar cells but have exhibited low solar-energy-conversion efficiencies that hamper their commercialization. This project is investigating an alternative reaction to dramatically increase the efficiency of iodide-containing DSSCs, from their current world-record efficiency of ~12% to over 20%. The project promotes the progress of science and facilitates environmental stewardship. Outreach workshops accompany this research program with the aim of increasing the participation and interest of female middle-school students in research related to solar energy conversion.

The research is motivated by a new mechanism of operation for DSSCs and dye-sensitized functional assemblies for solar fuels where multiple-electron-transfer redox-shuttle chemistry is driven at molecular electrocatalysts co-anchored to dye-sensitized nanocrystalline TiO2. Fundamental studies include (i) surface-confined electrocatalysis of multiple-electron-transfer redox-shuttle oxidation, (ii) self-exchange electron transfer between molecules anchored to the TiO2 surface, and (iii) (slow) recombination of electrons in TiO2 with oxidized surface-anchored molecules. Several series of polymeric materials and Pt and Pd organometallic coordination compounds are synthesized and investigated for their ability to facilitate inner-sphere iodide oxidation electrocatalysis. The molecular structure of dyes is varied to identify those with the most rapid self-exchange electron transfer and slowest recombination. TiO2-bound electrocatalysts and dyes are studied simultaneously in order to interrogate the effects of several interacting functions and with the aim of realizing efficient light-driven iodide electrocatalysis. The electrocatalysis work is performed using a rotating ring-disk electrode setup and/or cyclic voltammetry to assess the catalytic competency of the molecules. Dye phenomena are interrogated using spectroelectrochemistry and nanosecond pump-probe transient-absorption and time-resolved photoluminescence (polarization) spectroscopies. In addition to spectrally modeling transient spectra and polarization kinetics, numerical models and Monte Carlo simulations helps clarify what controls the rate of (desired) self-exchange electron transfer and (undesired) recombination.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most high-efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells use molecular dyes bound to high-surface-area nanocrystalline TiO2 thin films and an iodine-based liquid electrolyte. While these solar cells are somewhat efficient (>10%), they are not competitive with the >20% efficiencies of silicon-based solar cells. The biggest reason for this is that iodine-based electrolytes undergo complex multiple-electron-transfer reactions that enable somewhat efficient operation, by slowing interfacial charge recombination, but also hinder more efficient operation by requiring large overpotentials for dye regeneration. Therefore, in an effort to overcome this limitation, we worked toward understanding how iodide oxidation chemistry directly to triiodide could be catalyzed at molecular dyes bound to high-surface-area TiO2 thin films. Notably, we identified important considerations when utilizing techniques to measure kinetic processes related to these solar cells, including rates of interfacial self-exchange electron transfer using cyclic voltammetry and chronoamperometry, and rates of electrocatalysis using a modified version of Saveant’s Foot-of-the-Wave analysis. We also developed an X-band time-resolved microwave conductivity apparatus to specifically monitor dynamics of electrons in the TiO2 semiconductor. Using these techniques we showed that near-infrared-absorbing Os(II)–polypyridyl coordination compound dye sensitizers, which exhibit little overpotential to perform iodide oxidation from their Os(III) redox states, are not good electrocatalysts. Although we synthesized and screened many electrocatalyst candidates, unfortunately we were unable to identify any that were effective at driving iodide oxidation at high rates and low overpotentials. We also developed numerical Monte Carlo models that could simulate these processes under pulsed-laser excitation or continuous-wave excitation, and used the results to predict behavior and optimal conditions that could result in high-efficiency solar cell performance. This work serves as a stepping stone toward increasing the efficiency of dye-sensitized solar cells. This project also included significant outreach activities with participants in the UCI Tech Trek summer camp for middle-school-aged women. Over the course of the project we taught ~200 participants how to make dye-sensitized solar cells in order to increase their interest and excitement about careers in STEM.


Last Modified: 12/07/2020
Modified by: Shane Ardo
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Most high-efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells use molecular dyes bound to high-surface-area nanocrystalline TiO2 thin films and an iodine-based liquid electrolyte. While these solar cells are somewhat efficient (>10%), they are not competitive with the >20% efficiencies of silicon-based solar cells. Therefore, in an effort to overcome this limitation, we worked toward understanding how iodide oxidation chemistry directly to triiodide could be catalyzed at molecular dyes bound to high-surface-area TiO2 thin films. Notably, we identified important considerations when utilizing techniques to measure kinetic processes related to these solar cells, including rates of interfacial self-exchange electron transfer using cyclic voltammetry and chronoamperometry, and rates of electrocatalysis using a modified version of Saveant’s Foot-of-the-Wave analysis. We also developed an X-band time-resolved microwave conductivity apparatus to specifically monitor dynamics of electrons in the TiO2 semiconductor. Using these techniques we showed that near-infrared-absorbing Os(II)–polypyridyl coordination compound dye sensitizers, which exhibit little overpotential to perform iodide oxidation from their Os(III) redox states, are not good electrocatalysts. This work serves as a stepping stone toward increasing the efficiency of dye-sensitized solar cells. This project also included significant outreach activities with participants in the UCI Tech Trek summer camp for middle-school-aged women. Over the course of the project we taught ~200 participants how to make dye-sensitized solar cells in order to increase their interest and excitement about careers in STEM.
